notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed after January 5, 1863. Whitman's date of "Jan. 63" at the top of the page likely refers both to his visit(s) with Union soldier T. H. B. Geiger and the composition of the manuscript. Geiger was wounded at the Battle of Fredericksburg, December 11–15, 1862. His arm was amputated on January 5, 1863 at Armory Square Hospital, and he remained hospitalized there after the amputation (see Walt Whitman, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts, ed. Edward F. Grier [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 2:604n24).

body.p: the badly wounded are generally in good spirits—the sick, those low with fevers &c are disheartened and out of sorts

—T. H. B. Geiger, Geigers MillsCo B, 53d Penn enlisted in Oct. '61, is a young Berks Co. Pennsylvania lad, from Geiger's Mills, county, Berks co Pa—has a brother in the army was at Fair Oaks, and through the seven days battles on the Peninsula —is one of a family of 14 children 10 boys—was at Fredericksburgh, wounded, lost his right fore-arm,—an intelligent friendly young man,—was brought up from the front to Armory (bullet wound atin leg also.)—arm amputated there 5th January—has been doing well ever since—expresses satisfaction with his treatment, doctors, &c in the hospital. Still there the young man is, with his right arm gone, a memento of war, one of thousands & thousands. I talk with him awhile, ask him if he is going to have an artifial arm? Yes, when he gets home, he thinks—says the government does not give artificial arms to the soldiers. They give legs, but not arms.
